title: How many verb tenses are there in English? - Anna Ananichuk

options.text: To describe the physical location of the action

options.text: To express time without explicitly naming time periods

options.text: To indicate the speaker's emotions about the action

multiple-choice.question: How many aspects are there in English?
What is the main difference between the past simple and past perfect tenses?

options.label: A
options.text: The past simple describes an action that started and ended in the past, while the past perfect describes an action that started before another action in the past.

options.label: B
options.text: The past simple describes an action that started and ended in the past, while the past perfect describes an action that started and ended in the present.

options.label: C
options.text: The past simple describes an action that started and ended in the present, while the past perfect describes an action that started and ended in the past.

options.label: D
options.text: The past simple describes an action that started and ended in the present, while the past perfect describes an action that started and ended in the future.

multiple-choice.question: Which aspect describes an action that is still happening at the time of reference?
What is the total number of possible tenses in English?
Which language has no verb tenses at all, only aspect?
What is the main difference between the future simple and future perfect tenses?

options.label: A
options.text: The future simple describes an action that will start and end in the future, while the future perfect describes an action that will start before another action in the future.

options.label: B
options.text: The future simple describes an action that will start and end in the future, while the future perfect describes an action that will start and end in the present.

options.label: C
options.text: The future simple describes an action that will start and end in the present, while the future perfect describes an action that will start and end in the future.

options.label: D
options.text: The future simple describes an action that will start and end in the present, while the future perfect describes an action that will start and end in the past.

multiple-choice.question: Which language splits past tense into multiple degrees, like whether something happened hours, weeks, or years ago?
What is the main difference between the present simple and present perfect tenses?

options.label: A
options.text: The present simple describes an action that is happening now, while the present perfect describes an action that started in the past and continues up to the present.

options.label: B
options.text: The present simple describes an action that is happening now, while the present perfect describes an action that started and ended in the past.

options.label: C
options.text: The present simple describes an action that is happening now, while the present perfect describes an action that started and ended in the present.

options.label: D
options.text: The present simple describes an action that is happening now, while the present perfect describes an action that started and ended in the future.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the simple and continuous or progressive aspects?

options.label: A
options.text: The simple aspect describes an action that is still happening at the time of reference, while the continuous or progressive aspect describes an action that has started and ended.

options.label: B
options.text: The simple aspect describes an action that has started and ended, while the continuous or progressive aspect describes an action that is still happening at the time of reference.

options.label: C
options.text: The simple aspect describes an action that is still happening at the time of reference, while the continuous or progressive aspect describes an action that has started and ended.

options.label: D
options.text: The simple aspect describes an action that has started and ended, while the continuous or progressive aspect describes an action that is still happening at the time of reference.

title: Why incompetent people think they're amazing - David Dunning

multiple-choice.question: What is the Dunning-Kruger effect?

options.label: A
options.text: A psychological phenomenon where people underestimate their abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: A psychological phenomenon where people overestimate their abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: A phenomenon where people's abilities are unaffected by their self-perception.

options.label: D
options.text: A phenomenon where people's self-perception is unaffected by their abilities.

multiple-choice.question: How many studies have shown that people consistently rate themselves as better than average?
Who is most likely to overrate their skills?

options.label: B
options.text: People with a moderate amount of experience or expertise.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason for the Dunning-Kruger effect?
What can help overcome the Dunning-Kruger effect?
Why do experts tend to be aware of their knowledge but assume others are knowledgeable as well?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are confident in their abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are aware of their limitations.

options.label: C
options.text: Because they assume others are knowledgeable.

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are unaware of their knowledge.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of people being unskilled and unable to see their own faults?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less confident in their abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: They become aware of their limitations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of people being exceptionally competent and not perceiving how unusual their abilities are?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more confident in their abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: They become less confident in their abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: They become aware of their limitations.

multiple-choice.question: What is the old proverb that summarizes the Dunning-Kruger effect?

options.label: A
options.text: "When arguing with a fool, first make sure the other person isn't doing the same thing."

options.label: B
options.text: "When arguing with a fool, first make sure you are doing the same thing."

options.label: C
options.text: "When arguing with a fool, first make sure you are not doing the same thing."

options.label: D
options.text: "When arguing with a fool, first make sure the other person is not a fool."

multiple-choice.question: What is the main takeaway from the Dunning-Kruger effect?

options.label: A
options.text: People are generally aware of their abilities.

options.label: B
options.text: People tend to overestimate their abilities.

options.label: C
options.text: People tend to underestimate their abilities.

options.label: D
options.text: People's abilities are unaffected by their self-perception.

title: Can you solve the egg drop riddle? - Yossi Elran

multiple-choice.question: The Fabergé Egg Museum is a 100-story building with a single egg displayed on each floor.
The jewel thief plans to steal the egg at the top of the building because it is the most valuable.
The thief uses two souvenir eggs to test the fall of the eggs.
The experiment can only be repeated until both replica eggs are smashed.
The thief drops the first egg from different floors at larger intervals to narrow down the range where the critical floor can be found.
Smaller intervals work much better than large ones.
The thief uses the equation to solve for the first floor she needs to start with in the 100-floor building.
The thief needs to start on the 1st floor, moving up to the 10th, the 20th, and so on.
The thief needs to start on the 14th floor, moving up to the 27th, the 39th, and so on, for a maximum of 14 drops.
The thief can't pull a heist without breaking a few eggs.
